items.title: The Cadillac Optiq EV and Cadillac Escalade IQ go big on tech, luxury, and price
23andMe faces an uncertain future — so does your genetic data
AI chip startup FuriosaAI reportedly turns down $800M acquisition offer from Meta
items.summary:
- FuriosaAI, a South Korean startup, has rejected an $800 million acquisition offer from Meta.
- The decision to turn down the offer was due to disagreements over post-acquisition business strategy and organizational structure.
- FuriosaAI aims to develop and produce its AI chips independently, which includes chips called Warboy and Renegade (RNGD).
- The startup is also reportedly in talks to raise approximately $48 million and plans to launch RNGD chips later this year.

items.title: Ex-Network International execs raise $6M for Enza, an African fintech serving banks
items.author: Hany Fekry, Hamish Houston
items.summary:
- Enza, a fintech founded by ex-Network International executives, raised $6 million in seed funding.
- The startup targets banks and fintechs, offering local payment solutions including cards, wallets, and real-time payments.
- Enza aims to improve financial access for underserved businesses in Africa, initially focusing on Egypt, Nigeria, and South Africa.
- The company has secured over 10 million monthly transactions through partnerships with several banks.
- New funding will be used for team expansion and product development across Africa.

items.title: DNA testing company 23andMe files for bankruptcy protection, CEO resigns
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- 23andMe has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to initiate asset sale.
- CEO Anne Wojcicki resigns to become an independent bidder for the company.
- Company has faced financial and operational challenges, including a 99% drop in market capitalization.
- In 2023, a cyberattack compromised data of nearly 7 million customers.
- 23andMe settled a lawsuit related to the data breach for $30 million in September 2024.
- Current market value is around $48 million, with stock trading at $1.79.

items.title: Former Cruise CEO Kyle Vogt’s new robotics startup reportedly raises another $150M
items.author: Kyle Vogt, Paril Jain, Luke Holoubek
items.summary:
- The Bot Company, founded by Kyle Vogt, raised $150 million in a funding round led by Greenoaks.
- The startup aims to produce a robot focused on household chores and was launched in May 2024 with an initial $150 million.
- This funding comes less than a year after Vogt resigned as CEO of Cruise following a significant incident involving a Cruise vehicle.

items.title: Buy now, pay later . . . for a burrito?
items.summary:
- In 2010, a programmer spent 10,000 bitcoin on two pizzas, worth $850 million today.
- DoorDash partners with Klarna to allow customers to buy food and pay later in four interest-free payments for orders over $35.
- Concerns arise about customers missing payments and accruing late fees, highlighting economic worries.

items.title: Barack Obama joins Bluesky
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Barack Obama has joined Bluesky, a social network alternative to X (formerly Twitter).
- His account was confirmed by Bluesky OOO Rose Wang.
- Obama celebrated the 15th anniversary of the Affordable Care Act in his initial posts.
- He has a significant following on platforms like X (130.6 million followers) and Facebook (55 million followers).
- Bluesky has gained over 33 million users, benefiting from the exodus of users from X after the 2024 U.S. elections.
- Other notable politicians on Bluesky include Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

items.title: Browser Use, the tool making it easier for AI ‘agents’ to navigate websites, raises $17M
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Browser Use raised $17 million in seed funding led by Felicis’ Astasia Myers.
- Founded by Magnus Müller and Gregor Zunic, the company simplifies website navigation for AI agents by converting web elements into a more digestible format.
- The tool is gaining traction within Y Combinator’s 2025 winter batch, with over 20 companies using it to improve agent navigation on their websites.

items.title: Jonah Peretti helped shaped digital media — can he do it again?
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- Jonah Peretti, as the CEO of [BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/), has been a significant figure in digital media for nearly two decades.
- BuzzFeed has transformed from a startup to a multimedia powerhouse, but faces questions about its long-term strategy and stability.
- Peretti emphasizes his adaptability in a constantly changing media landscape, focusing on AI-driven content and projects like BF Island.
- BuzzFeed sold assets, including Complex Networks and First We Feast, reflecting challenges in maintaining its business model.
- The company's stock has dropped significantly, from an initial price of $10 to $2.20 per share, raising concerns among shareholders.
- Peretti argues that experimentation and innovation are crucial in navigating the evolving media market, despite the risks involved.

items.title: Charlie Javice trial becomes a master class in hubris for both sides
items.summary:
- Charlie Javice's fraud trial focuses on her allegedly deceiving JPMorgan Chase into acquiring her startup Frank for $175 million, despite having only 300,000 customers.
- Former Frank engineer Patrick Vovor testified that Javice requested him to create fake user data but refused, prompting her to seek help from a math professor instead.
- The trial reveals that JPMorgan did not thoroughly vet Frank's user base, highlighting a lack of due diligence in the deal.

items.title: Week in Review: Google buys Wiz
items.author: Karyne Levy
items.summary:
- Google confirmed its acquisition of Wiz for $32 billion, marking its largest acquisition ever.
- Wiz will be positioned as a multicloud offering, not limited to Google’s ecosystem.
- The acquisition follows a previous offer of $23 billion made by Google last year.
- Other highlights included xAI's acquisition of Hotshot and two NASA astronauts returning from the ISS after nine months.
- Google unveiled the Pixel 9a, priced at $499, featuring a brighter display and redesigned camera placement.
- A breach at the Pennsylvania State Education Association resulted in the theft of personal data of over 500,000 members.

items.title: The 20 hottest open source startups of 2024
items.author: null
items.summary:
- A new report by Runa Capital lists the 20 top-trending open source startups, with 11 closely linked to AI.
- The ROSS Index ranks startups based on GitHub stars, highlighting significant projects.
- Ollama, a Y Combinator alum, topped the list for its LLM running tool, gaining 76,000 stars in 2024.
- Other notable startups include Zed Industries, LangGenius, ComfyUI, and All Hands, each showing significant growth in GitHub stars.
- The report emphasizes the importance of tools for AI and developer-oriented technologies.

items.title: Meta settles UK ‘right to object to ad-tracking’ lawsuit by agreeing not to track plaintiff
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- Tanya O’Carroll, a human rights campaigner, forced Meta to stop using her data for targeted advertising.
- Settlement ends a lawsuit started in 2022 regarding her right to object to data processing for direct marketing.
- Meta claimed personalized ads are not direct marketing, but the settlement sets a precedent for others to object to data usage.

items.title: Anduril might build a weapons factory in the UK
Meta has revenue sharing agreements with Llama AI model hosts, filing reveals
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that selling access to Llama AI models is not their primary business model, but they do have revenue-sharing agreements.
- A court filing reveals Meta shares a portion of revenue from companies hosting Llama models, although specific hosts are not detailed.
- Notable Llama host partners include AWS, Nvidia, Databricks, Groq, Dell, Azure, Google Cloud, and Snowflake.
- Developers can run Llama models independently but often utilize hosts for additional services.
- Zuckerberg mentioned potential monetization strategies for Llama, including licensing and ads.
- The revenue generation is significant due to ongoing copyright litigation regarding alleged training on pirated materials.
- Meta plans large capital expenditures for AI, estimating $60 billion-$80 billion in 2025 primarily for data centers and AI development.

items.title: How BYD plans to make EV charging as fast as filling a gas tank
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- BYD's Han L sedan can add up to 248 miles of range in just five minutes of charging.
- The vehicle features an 83.2 kWh lithium-iron-phosphate battery operating at approximately 945 volts.
- BYD's dual gun charging system allows the car to charge at 1 megawatt, utilizing two ports simultaneously.
- Realistic range from a five-minute charge is approximately 160 miles due to optimistic testing cycles.
- BYD plans to install over 4,000 charging stations across China, with significant upgrades needed for existing infrastructure.
- Current U.S. market challenges may delay BYD's entry due to tariffs on Chinese EVs.

items.title: Valve removes video game demo suspected of being malware
items.summary:
- Valve removed the video game demo for Sniper: Phantom’s Resolution from its online store, Steam, after user reports of malware installation.
- The game promised realistic first-person shooter mechanics, dynamic storytelling, and high-stakes missions.
- Reports of the malware stemmed from Reddit users who analyzed the demo, leading to its removal, reminiscent of a previous incident with PirateFi in February.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's chatbot app reached the top of the Apple App Store and Google Play charts, gaining significant attention.
- The company, backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, started as a lab in 2023, focusing on AI tools.
- DeepSeek launched its first AI models in November 2023, gaining industry recognition with the release of its next-gen models in 2024.
- Their models outperform competitors while being cheaper, leading rivals to lower their prices or offer free services.
- Challenges include U.S. export bans and scrutiny from Chinese regulators regarding content output.
- Some entities, including Microsoft, have started to incorporate DeepSeek models into their services, despite ongoing national security concerns leading to government bans in various countries.

items.title: TechCrunch has, yes, personal news!
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- TechCrunch has been acquired by Regent, a private equity firm.
- The deal ensures minimal disruption to operations with a move to new offices in SoMa.
- Yahoo retains a small interest in TechCrunch, recognizing its unique position within its portfolio.
- The leadership team and expert journalists remain intact, committed to original reporting and news analysis.
- TechCrunch has continued to grow its readership amidst challenges in the news industry.

items.title: Anthropic appears to be using Brave to power web searches for its Claude chatbot
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic launched a web search feature for its AI chatbot Claude.
- Evidence indicates that Brave Search is powering Claude's web search functionality.
- Brave previously collaborated with Mistral to provide search capabilities for their chatbot, Le Chat.
- Other AI companies, like OpenAI, maintain undisclosed partnerships for web search services.
- Anthropic has not confirmed the partnership with Brave but included it in the subprocessors list for Claude.

items.title: Startups Weekly: Wiz’s bet paid off in an M&A-rich week
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Wiz walks away from a $23 billion offer from Google, which later agrees to acquire Wiz for a record $32 billion in cash, plus $1 billion in retention bonuses.
- SoftBank to acquire Ampere Computing for $6.5 billion in an all-cash deal.
- Next Insurance gets acquired by Munich Re for $2.6 billion.
- Nvidia reportedly acquires Gretel, a synthetic data startup, for over $320 million.
- Klarna signs as Walmart's exclusive BNPL partner after its IPO filing.
- Flexport sues former employees for allegedly stealing code to create a rival startup, Freightmate AI.
- New startup Spangle AI aims to create custom landing pages for e-commerce shoppers, launched by former Bolt CEO.
- Evroc raises $55 million for a European hyperscale cloud project.
- Graphite, an AI-powered code-review platform, secures $52 million in funding.

items.title: TechCrunch Mobility: Inside Waymo’s deal with SFO, Elon’s moment of truth, and BYD’s breakthrough
items.summary:
- Waymo has struck a deal with San Francisco Airport to map airport roadways, with future potential for robotaxi expansion.
- The agreement includes data-sharing requirements and prohibits the use of autonomous vehicles for moving commercial goods.
- Coreshell raised $24 million in funding; Einride may file for an IPO valuing at over $5 billion; Evera raised 2 million euros; Leta secured $5 million in seed funding; Seadronix received $11.3 million in Series B funding.
- BYD announced innovative EV charging technology; Honda and Acura will access Tesla’s Supercharger network in June; Tesla recalled 46,000 Cybertrucks for safety issues; Elon Musk faces scrutiny regarding his role in his companies amidst a crisis.

items.title: ChatGPT: Everything you need to know about the AI-powered chatbot
items.summary:
- ChatGPT, launched by OpenAI in November 2022, has gained popularity with over [300 million weekly active users](https://www.theinformation.com/briefings/openai-surpasses-300-million-weekly-active-users).
- In 2024, OpenAI announced partnerships (e.g., with Apple for generative AI) and new releases like [GPT-4o with voice capabilities](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/12/chatgpt-now-understands-real-time-video-seven-months-after-openai-first-demoed-it/) and the text-to-video model Sora.
- OpenAI faced legal challenges, including lawsuits and scrutiny over its transition to a for-profit structure, and internal departures of execs like [Ilya Sutskever](https://techcrunch.com/2024/05/14/ilya-sutskever-openai-co-founder-and-longtime-chief-scientist-departs/?utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=tc&utm_campaign=tc_week_in_review).
- Notable developments in 2025 include a [privacy complaint in Europe](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/19/chatgpt-hit-with-privacy-complaint-over-defamatory-hallucinations/) and upgrades to transcription and voice-generating models.
- OpenAI reported plans to [charge up to $20,000 a month](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/05/openai-reportedly-plans-to-charge-up-to-20000-a-month-for-specialized-ai-agents/?utm_campaign=tc_week_in_review&utm_medium=newsletter&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-8FzNR8H1_dsObV2gcIx4Q_s93NalU5zuUUx-jctJ62xqnRwNGxc2gr5utyX0DuL-91VpBVongHzoJ8hJ3OehgsNFdCBQ&_hsmi=350636795&utm_source=tc) for AI agents aimed at various applications.

items.title: Wayve CEO shares his key ingredients for scaling autonomous driving tech
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Wayve's CEO Alex Kendall outlines a strategy for scaling autonomous driving tech focusing on affordability and hardware flexibility.
- The company utilizes a data-driven learning approach relying on sensors without HD maps.
- Wayve has raised over $1.3 billion and is in discussions with multiple OEMs to integrate its software into various vehicle types.
- The software works with existing sensors, making it cost-effective for automotive partners.
- Wayve's AI aims to achieve Level 4 autonomy and incorporates lidar for improved performance.
- Kendall reveals GAIA-2, an advanced generative world model for training autonomous driving AI.

items.title: Microsoft is exploring a way to credit contributors to AI training data
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft is launching a research project to estimate the influence of specific training examples on AI model outputs.
- The project aims to provide recognition and potential compensation for contributors of training data.
- There are ongoing legal challenges against Microsoft regarding AI training data usage, with major firms advocating for fair use in AI practices.
- Jaron Lanier, a prominent technologist, is involved, emphasizing the concept of 'data dignity'.
- Current large AI labs have limited programs to compensate data contributors.
- Microsoft's initiative stands out amidst calls from other labs to weaken copyright protections related to AI.

items.title: Meta Spotted Testing AI-Generated Comments on Instagram
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Meta is testing an AI feature that suggests comments for Instagram posts.
- Users can access AI-generated suggestions by tapping a pencil icon next to the text bar under posts.
- The AI analyzes photos and generates three comment suggestions, which users can refresh if needed.
- The feature has not yet been rolled out widely and may not be well-received by users desiring genuine interactions on the platform.
- Testing of AI comments was previously conducted on Facebook last year.

items.title: 1X will test humanoid robots in ‘a few hundred’ homes in 2025
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Norwegian robotics startup 1X plans to test its humanoid robot, Neo Gamma, in "a few hundred to a few thousand" homes by the end of 2025.
- Tests will involve early adopters who will help teach Neo Gamma how to behave in a home environment.
- The robot relies on teleoperators for control as it is not fully autonomous yet.
- Neo Gamma features an improved AI model and a knitted nylon body suit to reduce injury risk.
- Each test will gather data to improve the robot's functionalities, despite raising privacy concerns regarding data collection from homes.

items.title: Commercial services platform BuildOps becomes a unicorn, raises $127M
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- BuildOps raised $127 million in a Series C round, achieving a post-money valuation of $1 billion.
- The funding was led by Meritech Capital and brings total funding to over $250 million.
- Founded in 2018, BuildOps provides AI-powered field service management software for commercial contractors in the U.S. and Canada.
- The company has over 1,000 customers and has seen significant revenue growth since launching its platform in 2020.
- Future plans include expanding headcount, technology investment, and potential strategic acquisitions.

items.title: Russian Zero-Day Seller Offers Up to $4 Million for Telegram Exploits
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Operation Zero, a company selling zero-days to the Russian government, is seeking exploits for Telegram.
- Offers up to $4 million for a 'full chain' of exploits, up to $1.5 million for a zero-click RCE exploit, and $500,000 for a one-click RCE exploit.
- The focus on Telegram is strategic due to its popularity in Russia and Ukraine, indicating government demand.
- Zero-days are valuable for being unknown to software makers, allowing hackers to exploit technology effectively.
- RCE exploits are highly sought after as they enable remote control over apps or systems.
- The bounty coincides with Ukraine's ban of Telegram for military personnel due to security concerns.
- Experts warn about Telegram's security, as it lacks robust end-to-end encryption compared to competitors.
- Some industry insiders believe advertised prices are low, noting potential for higher resale value.

items.title: Google claims news is worthless to its ad business after test involving 1% of search results in eight EU markets
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- Google conducted a test in eight EU markets, removing news from search results for 1% of users for 2.5 months.
- The experiment aimed to assess the value of news to Google's ad business, revealing that its value could not be statistically distinguished from zero.
- This outcome may influence Google's payment negotiations with European publishers amidst ongoing scrutiny and past antitrust fines related to news content.

items.title: GTC felt more bullish than ever, but Nvidia’s challenges are piling up
items.author: Charles Rollet, Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Nvidia attracted a record 25,000 attendees at GTC 2025 in San Jose.
- CEO Jensen Huang projected confidence despite facing challenges from U.S. tariffs and competition from Chinese AI lab DeepSeek.
- Nvidia unveiled new powerful chips, including the Vera Rubin GPUs, which aim to double the performance of current models in AI inference.
- Concerns emerged regarding competition from companies like Cerebras and Groq, as well as major tech firms developing in-house AI chips.
- Nvidia's stock price fell around 4% after Huang's keynote, reflecting investor concerns.
- Huang reassured that tariffs would not significantly affect Nvidia in the short term but acknowledged potential long-term impacts.
- Nvidia announced plans to invest hundreds of billions in U.S. manufacturing to diversify its supply chain.
- The company also launched new AI supercomputers aimed at home users, priced at thousands of dollars each.

items.title: Apple faces lawsuit over Apple Intelligence delays
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Apple has been sued in federal court over alleged false advertising regarding Apple Intelligence features.
- Filed in U.S. District Court in San Jose, the suit seeks class-action status and damages for Apple Intelligence-capable device owners.
- Plaintiffs argue that promised AI features are significantly limited or absent, misleading consumers about product utility and performance.
- The lawsuit adds to Apple's challenges in delivering the anticipated Apple Intelligence capabilities.
- Recent reports indicate CEO Tim Cook has lost confidence in AI head John Giannandrea's ability to manage product development.

items.title: Federal judge blocks DOGE’s access to Social Security Administration’s banks of personal information
items.summary:
- A federal judge blocked Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) from accessing the Social Security Administration’s (SSA) personal information.
- Judge Ellen Hollander described DOGE's request as a "fishing expedition" without proper justification.
- The blocked access included sensitive data such as Social Security numbers and medical records, citing violations of federal privacy laws and cybersecurity risks.

items.title: Apple is reportedly losing $1B per year on its streaming service
items.summary:
- Apple is losing over $1 billion annually on its streaming service, Apple TV+.
- The company has spent around $5 billion on content each year since 2019, which was reduced to $4.5 billion in 2024.
- Apple TV+ has approximately 45 million subscribers, significantly fewer than competitors like Netflix, which leads with 301 million subscribers.

items.title: A high schooler built a website that lets you challenge AI models to a Minecraft build-off
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- The website [Minecraft Benchmark (MC-Bench)](https://mcbench.ai/) allows users to challenge AI models with Minecraft building prompts.
- AI models compete in head-to-head challenges, where users vote on the best creations without knowing which AI was responsible.
- Founded by 12th grader Adi Singh, the project aims to make AI benchmarking more accessible and engaging through familiar gaming mechanics.

items.title: North Korea launches new unit with a focus on AI hacking, per report
items.summary:
- North Korea's government is creating a new hacking group within the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB).
- The unit, named Research Center 227, will focus on developing offensive hacking technologies, including AI-based techniques.
- The group aims to enhance capabilities in stealing digital assets and responding to threats from North Korean hacking units abroad.
- Recent activities include targeting cryptocurrency exchanges, notably the $1.4 billion hack of Bybit.
- The U.S. NSA and FBI have accused North Korea's RGB of hacking and espionage.

items.title: Gwyneth Paltrow says Goop is growing just fine
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Gwyneth Paltrow updated on her company Goop in a [Vanity Fair](https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/story/gwyneth-paltrow-2025-interview) cover story.
- Goop, founded in 2008, has raised over $140 million from investors like Greycroft and G9 Ventures.
- Reports indicated Goop sales were flat since 2021, leading to layoffs and questioning of the brand's market position.
- Paltrow mentioned Goop is restructuring to optimize its EBITDA and claims revenue for 2024 is up 10% from 2023.
- Goop Beauty, G.Label fashion unit, and Goop Kitchen are reportedly seeing growth as part of the brand's recovery.
- Paltrow emphasizes seeing the increasing competition in the wellness sector as an opportunity rather than a threat.

items.title: Perplexity is reportedly in talks to raise up to $1B at an $18B valuation
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- AI-powered search startup Perplexity is in talks to raise up to $1 billion, valuing the company at $18 billion.
- Perplexity’s annual recurring revenue has reached $100 million.
- This funding round would double the company's previous valuation of $9 billion from December 2024.
- Competition in the AI search space has intensified, with companies like Anthropic and Google launching new AI products.
- Perplexity is expanding its market, teasing a new browser called Comet and enhancing enterprise offerings.

items.title: Apple puts Vision Pro exec in charge of Siri in exec shakeup
items.summary:
- Apple shakes up leadership for Siri due to dissatisfaction with current AI head John Giannandrea.
- Mike Rockwell, VP of the Vision Products Group, is appointed to lead Siri.
- Rockwell will report to software chief Craig Federighi; Paul Meade will lead the Vision Products Group.
- Siri is struggling against modern AI competitors, prompting integration of third-party AI services.
- Recent tests show Siri's inability to answer basic questions, leading to a delay in the rollout of more personalized features.

items.title: Apple puts Vision Pro exec in charge of Siri in exec shakeup
items.summary:
- Apple appoints Mike Rockwell, VP of the Vision Products Group, to lead the Siri team.
- Current AI head John Giannandrea is removed due to loss of confidence in his product development execution.
- Rockwell will report to software chief Craig Federighi, while Paul Meade takes over the Vision Products Group.
- Siri struggles against modern AI, prompting Apple to integrate third-party services like ChatGPT.
- Recent tests revealed Siri's inability to answer simple questions, and the rollout of personalized Siri features is delayed until next year.

items.title: Next Insurance gets scooped up by Munich Re for $2.6B
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Munich Re acquires Next Insurance for $2.6 billion.
- Next Insurance, based in Palo Alto, focuses on insurance for small-to-medium-sized businesses.
- The deal is expected to close in Q3 2025, subject to approvals.
- Next Insurance was last valued at $2.5 billion in late 2023 after raising $265 million.
- The company had over 600,000 customers and reported a revenue of $548 million in 2024.

items.title: Tesla Superchargers: GM, Ford, Rivian, and other EV brands with access
items.summary:
- In May 2023, Ford made a deal to give EV owners access to Tesla's Supercharger network.
- By the end of 2023, major automakers like GM, Hyundai, and Rivian also agreed to adopt Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS).
- As of February 2024, Ford customers officially gained access, but adapter delivery faced delays.
- GM updated its vehicles to allow access by September 2024, requiring a $225 adapter for earlier models.
- Honda announced NACS access for its EVs by June 2025, with future models to be built with NACS ports.
- Rivian gained access to Superchargers in March 2024, with adapters sent to customers starting April.
- Volvo and Polestar began offering Tesla Supercharger access in October 2024, including free adapters for new EV buyers.

items.title: AI’s answers on China differ depending on the language, analysis finds
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI models from Chinese labs like [DeepSeek](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/14/deepseek-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-ai-chatbot-app/) censor politically sensitive topics due to a 2023 law. 
- A developer, using the handle "xlr8harder", found that AI responses differ when questions are asked in different languages, particularly when addressing politically sensitive topics. 
- Models like Alibaba's [Qwen 2.5 72B Instruct](https://techcrunch.com/2025/03/20/ais-answers-on-china-differ-depending-on-the-language-analysis-finds/) were compliant in English but less so in Chinese; others like [R1 1776](https://www.perplexity.ai/fr/hub/blog/open-sourcing-r1-1776) also showed significant differences. 
- Experts noted these discrepancies could be due to varying amounts of training data and the influence of political censorship on AI model training.

items.title: Honda and Acura EV owners to gain access to Tesla Superchargers this June
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Honda and Acura EV owners will have access to Tesla's Supercharger network starting June.
- Owners of Honda Prologue and Acura ZDX will need to purchase Honda-approved charging adapters due to differences in charging port technology.
- Honda agreed in 2023 to adopt Tesla’s NACS standard and will release a new EV model in 2025 built with this standard.
- Notifications for adapter availability will be sent via HondaLink and Acura EV apps, which will also show Supercharger locations.

items.title: Gmail’s new AI search now sorts emails by relevance instead of chronological order
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announces a new update for Gmail that sorts emails by relevance instead of chronological order.
- AI will consider factors such as recency, most-clicked emails, and frequent contacts to improve search results.
- A toggle feature allows users to choose between “Most relevant” or “Most recent” email displays.
- The update is being rolled out globally for personal Google account users and is available on the web and mobile apps.
- This change aims to compete with Apple’s Mail app, which has introduced similar features recently.

items.title: CoreWeave prices its IPO to raise at least $2.2 billion. And now the games begin.
items.summary:
- CoreWeave is pricing its initial public shares between $47 and $55 per share, aiming to raise between $2.2 billion and $2.6 billion.
- Initially, the company hoped to raise at least $3 billion, potentially exceeding $4 billion.
- Pricing strategies often involve setting a lower initial range to create demand and excitement ahead of trading.
- CoreWeave secured a $12 billion customer agreement with OpenAI and appointed Meg Whitman to its board of directors recently.

items.title: Anthropic adds web search to its Claude chatbot
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic's AI chatbot Claude can now perform web searches, a previously unavailable feature.
- Web search is currently in preview for paid users in the U.S.; support for free users and additional countries will follow.
- Users can enable web search in their profile settings from the Claude web app, which will provide direct citations for information.
- This feature allows Claude to offer answers based on real-time insights, positioning it on par with competitors like ChatGPT, Google’s Gemini, and others.
- There are risks involved, such as the potential for hallucinations or incorrect citations from web sources, which is a common issue among chatbots.

items.title: OpenAI upgrades its transcription and voice-generating AI models
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI introduces new transcription and voice-generating models, enhancing its API capabilities.
- The text-to-speech model, gpt-4o-mini-tts, enables developers to customize the tone and style of speech.
- New speech-to-text models, gpt-4o-transcribe and gpt-4o-mini-transcribe, replace the older Whisper model, providing improved accuracy, especially in noisy environments.
- OpenAI won’t release the new models for open use, stating they are larger and necessitate careful consideration for an open-source release.
- Internal benchmarks show the new transcription models struggle with certain languages, obtaining a word error rate of nearly 30% for languages like Tamil and Telugu.

items.title: Threads adds new features to highlight topics and limit replies
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Meta's Threads rolls out new features to enhance user engagement and content relevance.
- Users can now add up to 10 topics of interest to their profiles for better post suggestions.
- New reply controls allow only followers to respond to specific posts, building on quote control features launched previously.
- Redesigned topic tags introduced for easier navigation of interest-based content.
- Enhanced video playback features include a more user-friendly player with better control options.
- Meta is reintroducing political content suggestions based on user preferences after a previous halt.
